instructions_en: Scores are based on patient responses to questions about pain intensity. 0 indicates no pain; 10 indicates the most pain imaginable. The NPS is only for use in patients who have already been diagnosed with neuropathic pain, and should not be used to determine IF a patient's pain is secondary to neuropathy.

seo.meta_description_en: The Neuropathic Pain Scale (NPS) assesses severity of neuropathic pain.
seo.keywords_en: neuropathic pain, neuropathy pain, neuropathic pain scale, nps scale, nps calculator, neuropathy pain severity

how_to_use.use_case_en: Known neuropathy patient being followed and evaluated over time.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
The Neuropathic Pain Scale (NPS) allows for standardized pain assessment in neuropathy patients.

Points to keep in mind:

  • The NPS quantifies already-diagnosed neuropathic pain.
  • It is NOT a diagnostic tool to determine if a patient's pain is neuropathic in origin.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Neuropathic pain is experienced quite variably and can be difficult to assess and follow.

next_steps.advice_en: The NPS is a comprehensive and wise method for assessing neuropathy pain and may be particularly useful for assessing response to therapies.

about.more_info_en: The higher the score, the worse the neuropathic pain. Consider appropriate analgesia.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Galer BS, Jensen MP. Development and preliminary validation of a pain measure specific to neuropathic pain: the Neuropathic Pain Scale. Neurology. 1997 Feb;48(2):332-8

Other References.text: Jensen MP, et al. The validity of the neuropathic pain scale for assessing diabetic neuropathic pain in a clinical trial. Clin J Pain. 2006 Jan;22(1):97-103

Validation.text: Rog DJ, et al. Validation and reliability of the Neuropathic Pain Scale (NPS) in multiple sclerosis. Clin J Pain. 2007 Jul-Aug;23(6):473-81

creator_info.about_en: Bradley S. Galer, MD, is the executive vice president and chief medical officer of Zogenix Pharmaceuticals. Dr. Galer has also held numerous other industry positions, both academic and clinical in scope. He has published over 200 articles on pain management in peer review journals and textbooks.
